vocabulary.description: A two-dimensional grid-based layout system designed for organizing content on web pages.
vocabulary.definition: A two-dimensional grid-based layout system designed for organizing content on web pages.
vocabulary.example: CSS Grid allows developers to create complex layouts with rows and columns simultaneously.

vocabulary.description: A one-dimensional layout method for arranging items in rows or columns, with flexible container dimensions.
vocabulary.definition: A one-dimensional layout method for arranging items in rows or columns, with flexible container dimensions.
vocabulary.example: Flexbox makes it simple to align items and distribute space within a container.

vocabulary.description: The technique of splitting your code into various bundles which can then be loaded on demand.
vocabulary.definition: The technique of splitting your code into various bundles which can then be loaded on demand.
vocabulary.example: Code splitting prevents loading unnecessary code and reduces initial load time.

vocabulary.description: A styling technique where JavaScript is used to style components, eliminating the need for CSS stylesheets.
vocabulary.definition: A styling technique where JavaScript is used to style components, eliminating the need for CSS stylesheets.
vocabulary.example: Libraries like styled-components and Emotion allow developers to write CSS directly within JavaScript files.

vocabulary.description: The process of rendering web pages on the server before sending them to the browser.
vocabulary.definition: The process of rendering web pages on the server before sending them to the browser.
vocabulary.example: Next.js is a popular framework that provides server-side rendering capabilities for React applications.
